The Dependent Type Theory of Lean

tags: mathematics lean

26 Oct 2019

In this blog post, we outline the foundational types of the type theory implemented in Lean. These types are simple types, dependent function types, and dependent product types.

Simple types

We start with an infinite hierarchy of simple types:

#check Prop
#check Type 0
#check Type 1
#check Type 2
#check Type 3

and so on, so that Type i : Type i+1 (we write a : α to say that “a is of type α. Notice that Type 0 can just be abbreviated to Type, and that Prop is the “most fundamental” type. The type Prop takes a special place in Lean, and has special properties which will not be discussed here, but possibly in a later post.

Dependent types

Now we encounter dependent types. There are two families of dependent types; these are dependent function types and dependent product types. Intuitively, these are the type theory versions of functions and Cartesian products (respectively) in set theory.

A dependent type is a type that depends on another type; in a sense the dependent type is “parametrised” by that type which is depended upon.

Dependent function types, or Π-types

The most basic construction of a Π-type (dependent function type) is the following:

variable α : Type
variable β : Type
#check Π (x : α), β

Let us declare a variable of the above type to see what’s going on:

variable α : Type
variable β : Type
variable f : Π (x : α), β
#check f

and we see that f is of the type α→β which is shorthand for Π (x : α), β.

But in what way is the above dependent type “dependent”? The fact of the matter is that it is not “dependent”. But now with the above “function type” we may construct a dependent type that is actually “dependent”.

variable α : Type
variable β : α → Type
-- we can also write it like this: variable β : Π x : α, Type
-- but the above notation is more enlightening and more simple
#check Π x : α, β x

Again, let us declare a variable of the above type:

variable α : Type
variable β : α → Type
variable g : Π x : α, β x

variable a : α

#check g
#check g a

and we see that g is like a function that takes in a term of type α and outputs a type β a, which clearly depends on the value that a takes. So the above type is more clearly “dependent”, and it’s got a “function”, so we call it a “dependent function type”.

Dependent product types, or Σ-types
